message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Continuous symmetry breaking in a two-dimensional Rydberg array
Paper Abstract: Spontaneous symmetry breaking underlies much of our classification of phases of matter and their associated transitions<sup>1-3</sup>. The nature of the underlying symmetry being broken determines many of the qualitative properties of the phase; this is illustrated by the case of discrete versus continuous symmetry breaking. Indeed, in contrast to the discrete case, the breaking of a continuous symmetry leads to the emergence of gapless Goldstone modes controlling, for instance, the thermodynamic stability of the ordered phase<sup>4,5</sup>. Here, we realize a two-dimensional dipolar XY model that shows a continuous spin-rotational symmetry using a programmable Rydberg quantum simulator. We demonstrate the adiabatic preparation of correlated low-temperature states of both the XY ferromagnet and the XY antiferromagnet. In the ferromagnetic case, we characterize the presence of a long-range XY order, a feature prohibited in the absence of long-range dipolar interaction. Our exploration of the many-body physics of XY interactions complements recent works using the Rydberg-blockade mechanism to realize Ising-type interactions showing discrete spin rotation symmetry<sup>6-9</sup>.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "XY model"

Links: [{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz–Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Nicolet 1080 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolet_1080"},{"title":"Ford Falcon (XY) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(XY)"},{"title":"Cutter location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutter_location"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)In general, the XY model can be seen as a specialization of Stanley's n-vector model for n = 2.

## Key Characteristics

The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.(no content)In the XY spin system, the spins can be represented as an arrow pointing in some direction, with each possible continuous variable represented as a spectrum of colors.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model varies significantly by dimension:

- **One Dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition.
- **Two Dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.
- **Three and Higher Dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.

## Physical Applications

Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)In general, the XY model can be seen as a specialization of Stanley's n-vector model for n = 2.

## Key Characteristics

The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.(no content)In the XY spin system, the spins can be represented as an arrow pointing in some direction, with each possible continuous variable represented as a spectrum of colors.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model varies significantly by dimension:

- **One Dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition.
- **Two Dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.
- **Three and Higher Dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.

## Physical Applications

Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.

Web search results for query: "Rydberg atom"

Links: [{"title":"Rydberg atom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_atom"},{"title":"Rydberg state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_state"},{"title":"Rydberg constant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_constant"},{"title":"Rydberg molecule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_molecule"},{"title":"Johannes Rydberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Rydberg"},{"title":"Rydberg polaron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_polaron"},{"title":"Heavy Rydberg system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heavy_Rydberg_system"},{"title":"Neutral atom quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_atom_quantum_computer"},{"title":"Rydberg matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_matter"},{"title":"Rydberg formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_formula"}]

## Rydberg Atom

A Rydberg atom is an excited atom with one or more electrons that have a very high principal quantum number, n. The higher the value of n, the farther the electron is from the nucleus, on average.

### Key Properties

The radius of the orbit scales as n², and Rydberg atoms are extremely large, with loosely bound valence electrons, easily perturbed or ionized by collisions or external fields.(no content)Because the binding energy of a Rydberg electron falls off like 1/n², the energy level spacing falls off like 1/n³ leading to ever more closely spaced levels converging on the first ionization energy.

### Historical Background

The existence of the Rydberg series was first demonstrated in 1885 when Johann Balmer discovered a simple empirical formula for the wavelengths of light associated with transitions in atomic hydrogen. Three years later, the Swedish physicist Johannes Rydberg presented a generalized and more intuitive version of Balmer's formula that came to be known as the Rydberg formula.

### Applications

Rydberg atoms are used to build neutral atom quantum computers, which is a type of quantum computers. Additionally, Rydberg matter is an exotic phase of matter formed by Rydberg atoms and has been formed from various elements like caesium, potassium, hydrogen and nitrogen.

Web search results for query: "Quantum simulator"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator"},{"title":"Cirq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirq"},{"title":"Hamiltonian simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_simulation"},{"title":"IBM Quantum Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Quantum_Platform"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QuTiP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QuTiP"},{"title":"Sofie Lindskov Hansen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofie_Lindskov_Hansen"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Quantum robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_robotics"}]

Here are the search results for "Quantum simulator":

## Overview

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion, with simulators being special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why Quantum Simulators Matter

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number, and better computational tools are needed to understand and rationally design materials whose properties depend on collective quantum behavior of hundreds of particles. Quantum simulators provide an alternative route to understanding the properties of these systems.

## Advantages

Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.(no content)These simulators create clean realizations of specific systems of interest, which allows precise realizations of their properties, and precise control over and broad tunability of parameters of the system allows the influence of various parameters to be cleanly disentangled.

## Experimental Platforms

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Recent Developments

Recently quantum simulators have been used to obtain time crystals and quantum spin liquids.

Web search results for query: "Goldstone mode"

Links: [{"title":"Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Goldstone Solar System Radar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_Solar_System_Radar"},{"title":"Goldstino - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstino"},{"title":"Supersolid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Supersolid"},{"title":"Goldstone (glass) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_(glass)"},{"title":"Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_Deep_Space_Communications_Complex"},{"title":"Talk:Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Goldstone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone"}]

Based on the search results, here's what a Goldstone mode is:

## Overview

In condensed matter physics, Goldstone modes are quasiparticles also known as Anderson–Bogoliubov modes.(no content)They are bosons that appear necessarily in models exhibiting spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries.

## Key Characteristics

The Nambu–Goldstone mode is a long-wavelength fluctuation of the corresponding order parameter.(no content)Spontaneous breaking of a continuous symmetry is inevitably accompanied by gapless (meaning that these modes do not cost any energy to excite) Nambu–Goldstone modes associated with slow, long-wavelength fluctuations of the order parameter.(no content)They can be thought of as the excitations of the field in the broken symmetry directions in group space—and are massless if the spontaneously broken symmetry is not also broken explicitly.

## Physical Examples

Goldstone modes appear in various physical systems:

- Vibrational modes in a crystal (phonons) are associated with slow density fluctuations of the crystal's atoms, and the Goldstone mode for magnets are oscillating waves of spin known as spin-waves.
- In fluids, the phonon is the Goldstone boson of the spontaneously broken Galilean symmetry, while in solids, the Goldstone bosons are the longitudinal and transverse phonons.

Based on the search results, here's what a Goldstone mode is:

## Overview

In condensed matter physics, Goldstone modes are quasiparticles also known as Anderson–Bogoliubov modes.(no content)They are bosons that appear necessarily in models exhibiting spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries.

## Key Characteristics

The Nambu–Goldstone mode is a long-wavelength fluctuation of the corresponding order parameter.(no content)Spontaneous breaking of a continuous symmetry is inevitably accompanied by gapless (meaning that these modes do not cost any energy to excite) Nambu–Goldstone modes associated with slow, long-wavelength fluctuations of the order parameter.(no content)They can be thought of as the excitations of the field in the broken symmetry directions in group space—and are massless if the spontaneously broken symmetry is not also broken explicitly.

## Physical Examples

Goldstone modes appear in various physical systems:

- Vibrational modes in a crystal (phonons) are associated with slow density fluctuations of the crystal's atoms, and the Goldstone mode for magnets are oscillating waves of spin known as spin-waves.
- In fluids, the phonon is the Goldstone boson of the spontaneously broken Galilean symmetry, while in solids, the Goldstone bosons are the longitudinal and transverse phonons.

Links: [{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Category:Ferromagnetic materials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ferromagnetic_materials"},{"title":"Ferromagnetic superconductor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetic_superconductor"},{"title":"Talk:Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Category:Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Curie temperature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curie_temperature"},{"title":"Superferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superferromagnetism"},{"title":"Saturation (magnetic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturation_(magnetic)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about ferromagnetism:

## Definition and Basic Properties

Ferromagnetism is a property of certain materials (such as iron) that results in a significant, observable magnetic permeability, and in many cases, a significant magnetic coercivity, allowing the material to form a permanent magnet.(no content)Ferromagnetism (along with the similar effect ferrimagnetism) is the strongest type and is responsible for the common phenomenon of everyday magnetism.

## Materials

The common ferromagnetic materials are the metals iron, cobalt, nickel and most of their alloys, and certain rare-earth metals.(no content)Ferromagnetism results from these materials having many unpaired electrons in their d-block (in the case of iron and its relatives) or f-block (in the case of the rare-earth metals), a result of Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity.

## Physical Mechanism

When a magnetic field is absent the material has spontaneous magnetization which is a result of the ordered magnetic moments; that is, for ferromagnetism, the atoms are symmetrical and aligned in the same direction creating a permanent magnetic field.(no content)Ferromagnetic materials (like iron) are composed of microscopic regions called magnetic domains, that act like tiny permanent magnets that can change their direction of magnetization. Before an external magnetic field is applied to the material, the domains' magnetic fields are oriented in random directions, effectively cancelling each other out, so the net external magnetic field is negligibly small.

## Applications

Ferromagnetism is widely used in industrial applications and modern technology, in electromagnetic and electromechanical devices such as electromagnets, electric motors, generators, transformers, magnetic storage (including tape recorders and hard disks), and nondestructive testing of ferrous materials.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Ising model"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

## Ising Model

The Ising model, named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics.(no content)The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).

### Structure and Dynamics

The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

### Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition.(no content)The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

### Significance

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)In statistical physics, the Ising model is the simplest system exhibiting a continuous phase transition with a scalar order parameter.(no content)Today, each year, about 800 papers are published that use the model to address problems in such diverse fields as neural networks, protein folding, biological membranes and social behavior.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Paramagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetic structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_structure"},{"title":"Talk:Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetochemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetochemistry"},{"title":"Multiferroics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiferroic"},{"title":"Amorphous magnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amorphous_magnet"},{"title":"Antiferromagnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Antiferromagnet&redirect=no"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of antiferromagnetism:

## Definition

In materials that exhibit antiferromagnetism, the magnetic moments of atoms or molecules, usually related to the spins of electrons, align in a regular pattern with neighboring spins (on different sublattices) pointing in opposite directions.

## Key Characteristics

When no external field is applied, the antiferromagnetic structure corresponds to a vanishing total magnetization. This distinguishes antiferromagnetism from ferromagnetism, where materials have a net magnetic moment.

Antiferromagnetic order may exist at sufficiently low temperatures, but vanishes at and above the Néel temperature – named after Louis Néel, who had first identified this type of magnetic ordering.(no content)Above the Néel temperature, the material is typically paramagnetic.

## Historical Background

The phenomenon of antiferromagnetism was first introduced by Lev Landau in 1933.(no content)Antiferromagnetic structures were first shown through neutron diffraction of transition metal oxides such as nickel, iron, and manganese oxides. The experiments, performed by Clifford Shull, gave the first results showing that magnetic dipoles could be oriented in an antiferromagnetic structure.

## Common Materials

Antiferromagnetic materials occur commonly among transition metal compounds, especially oxides. Examples include hematite, metals such as chromium, alloys such as iron manganese (FeMn), and oxides such as nickel oxide (NiO).

## Applications

Antiferromagnetism plays a crucial role in devices employing giant magnetoresistance (GMR), an effect discovered in 1988 by the Nobel Prize winners Albert Fert and Peter Grünberg (awarded in 2007). First, for antiferromagnets being employed as pinning layers and also since the original device design (iron-chromium-iron multilayer with the Cr layer thickness carefully tuned) amounts to a synthetic antiferromagnet.

Links: [{"title":"Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Paramagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetic structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_structure"},{"title":"Talk:Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Magnetochemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetochemistry"},{"title":"Multiferroics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiferroic"},{"title":"Amorphous magnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amorphous_magnet"},{"title":"Antiferromagnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Antiferromagnet&redirect=no"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of antiferromagnetism:

## Definition

In materials that exhibit antiferromagnetism, the magnetic moments of atoms or molecules, usually related to the spins of electrons, align in a regular pattern with neighboring spins (on different sublattices) pointing in opposite directions.

## Key Characteristics

When no external field is applied, the antiferromagnetic structure corresponds to a vanishing total magnetization. This distinguishes antiferromagnetism from ferromagnetism, where materials have a net magnetic moment.

Antiferromagnetic order may exist at sufficiently low temperatures, but vanishes at and above the Néel temperature – named after Louis Néel, who had first identified this type of magnetic ordering.(no content)Above the Néel temperature, the material is typically paramagnetic.

## Historical Background

The phenomenon of antiferromagnetism was first introduced by Lev Landau in 1933.(no content)Antiferromagnetic structures were first shown through neutron diffraction of transition metal oxides such as nickel, iron, and manganese oxides. The experiments, performed by Clifford Shull, gave the first results showing that magnetic dipoles could be oriented in an antiferromagnetic structure.

## Common Materials

Antiferromagnetic materials occur commonly among transition metal compounds, especially oxides. Examples include hematite, metals such as chromium, alloys such as iron manganese (FeMn), and oxides such as nickel oxide (NiO).

## Applications

Antiferromagnetism plays a crucial role in devices employing giant magnetoresistance (GMR), an effect discovered in 1988 by the Nobel Prize winners Albert Fert and Peter Grünberg (awarded in 2007). First, for antiferromagnets being employed as pinning layers and also since the original device design (iron-chromium-iron multilayer with the Cr layer thickness carefully tuned) amounts to a synthetic antiferromagnet.

Web search results for query: "Symmetry breaking"

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of symmetry breaking:

## Definition

Symmetry breaking is a phenomenon in physics where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT) and contemporary understandings of physics.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types: explicit and spontaneous, which are characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking (SSB):** In SSB, the equations of motion of the system are invariant, but any vacuum state (lowest energy state) is not.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** Explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

## Key Application: The Higgs Mechanism

Symmetry breaking plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)Gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.

## Biological Applications

In biology, symmetry breaking is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Continuous symmetry breaking in a two-dimensional Rydberg array". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** (the paper proposes a novel experimental realization of a 2D XY model using Rydberg atoms)

**Key Entities Extracted**: 8 triples total

### Triples Identified:

1. **Symmetry breaking** (concept) - The paper demonstrates continuous symmetry breaking, a fundamental concept in phase transitions
2. **Classical XY model** (concept) - Proposes a novel 2D dipolar XY model realization using Rydberg atoms
3. **Rydberg atom** (tool) - Used as the physical platform for the quantum simulator
4. **Quantum simulator** (tool) - Proposes a programmable Rydberg quantum simulator
5. **Goldstone boson** (concept) - Characterizes gapless Goldstone modes that control thermodynamic stability
6. **Ferromagnetism** (concept) - Demonstrates long-range XY ferromagnetic order enabled by dipolar interactions
7. **Antiferromagnetism** (concept) - Explores low-temperature states of the XY antiferromagnet
8. **Ising model** (concept) - Contrasts with discrete spin rotation symmetry work using Ising interactions

All triples have been properly documented with Wikipedia URLs and relevance statements. The validation script confirms all entries are correctly formatted and validated.

**Validation Status**: ✅ All checks passed!

Sources:
- [Symmetry breaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking)
- [Classical XY model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model)
- [Rydberg atom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_atom)
- [Quantum simulator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator)
- [Goldstone boson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson)
- [Ferromagnetism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism)
- [Antiferromagnetism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism)
- [Ising model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model)
